ygData.msgSnippet: ... Why not just have a complete set of test cases, and use a random subset of those for each evaluation?  Evolution will be noisier, but should still converge

> I do foresee one problem though which became apparent in my multiplexer
>=
 experiments. If we tesselate multiple functions together (and they need
> =
not be repetitions of the same function) then we now have a far larger
> co=
mbination of input values to test against, e.g. in binary input
> problems =
such as XOR the number of test cases doubles with each extra
> input we add=
. This of course corresponds to more time per network
> evaluation and so t=
he idea doesn't scale quite as well as might be
> apparent at first.

Why n=
ot just have a complete set of test cases, and use a random
subset of those=
 for each evaluation?  Evolution will be noisier, but
should still converge=
 with fewer evaluations.
